After using Lexan for years, we’re thinking about doing an inverted bellypan using 1/4" birch. But how do we keep it from looking…um… woody?

Champ in the making!"},"post_url":"/t/show-me-yo-wood-bellypans/400246/3","custom_user_title":"Yo! Champ in the making!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2991900,"name":"","username":"BrendanB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brendanb/{size}/236167_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-15T00:32:29.652Z","cooked":"

Sometimes making wood look less wood like doesn’t pay off in the long run. Anytime we’ve tried covering up wood with paint you get small chips and flakes on the edges and looks worse even with touchup.

Rattlecan spray paint is just fine for a quick one-night job if really don’t like the look of wood.

but 4183 has made some neat looking wood undersides, that look woody, and it’s good wood

If cars have wood paneling why can’t robots?

Wait, I’ve got a better angle

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2022-01-15T04:08:47.472Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":293,"readers_count":292,"score":268.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":400246,"topic_slug":"show-me-yo-wood-bellypans","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/show-me-yo-wood-bellypans/400246/13","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":12},{"id":"cry","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":14,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2992005,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-15T04:14:08.057Z","cooked":"

Wood paneling used to indicate state-of-the-art technology! It was 40 years ago, but the aesthetic still holds up!

troy_dietz:

Wait, I’ve got a better angle

Still the moment that took me from “this robotics thing is pretty cool” to “this is my life now”.

Now you need to post the REST of them. Start with 2001, go until the BeachBots stopped using wood bellypans. (That would be somewhere around 2019, IIRC…)

The key to having a nice wooden bellypan is to start with nice plywood. Then you sand it, maybe seal it a bit, and when you’re installing make sure to put the screws in properly. 6mm baltic birch plus some sand-and-seal, and if you’re concerned about strength glue another layer on top, should come out nicely.
